{{refimprove|date=August 2011}} A '''news bureau''' is an office for gathering or distributing [[news]]. Similar terms are used for specialized bureaux, often to indicate geographic location or scope of coverage: a ‘Tokyo bureau’ refers to a given news operation's office in [[Tokyo]]; 'foreign bureau' is a generic term for a news office set up in a country other than the primary operations center; a ‘Washington bureau’ is an office, typically located in [[Washington, D.C.]], that covers news related to national politics in the [[United States]]. The person in charge of a news bureau is often called the bureau chief.
The term is distinct from a news desk, which refers to the editorial function of assigning reporters and other staff, and otherwise coordinating, news stories, and sometimes the physical desk where that occurs, but without regard to the geographic location or overall operation of the news organization. For example, a foreign bureau is located in a foreign country and refers to all creative and administrative operations that take place there, whereas a foreign desk describes only editorial functions and may be located anywhere, possibly as an organizational unit within the news organization's home office.
==Operation of news bureaux== A news bureau is traditionally operated out of an office by a single news outlet such as a radio, television, or newspaper news program. A single news company such as [[CNN]] or [[NPR]] may use a single bureau and office staff for all of its programs, and even those of [[subsidiary]] or other affiliated companies. For convenience, to save money and space, and to ensure the availability of necessary services (such as video feeds and studios), different companies may share an office space or co-locate at a single office building. [[News agencies]] may also operate news bureaux, and major public relations sources (such as governments, large companies, or advocacy groups) may operate news bureaux of their own to create, rather than simply report, news stories.
==History of news bureaux== <!-- ===Origin=== insert content here -->
===Decline===
Traditional [[news media]], particularly [[television news]] and [[newspapers]], have cut the number and size of news bureaux in recent decades for several reasons. They face declining profitability due to increasing competition from Internet news sources, and therefore have less money to spend on news-gathering.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2007-11-12|title=NBC Says Viewers Won’t Notice Cuts in News Staff|author=Jaques Steinberg|date=October 20, 2006|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/20/business/media/20nbc.html}}</ref>
Newspapers rely increasingly on cooperative arrangements with counterparts elsewhere, and often will accept stories from their sister organizations rather than investigating stories themselves. Similarly, smaller newspapers may formally affiliate to sponsor cooperative bureaux that operate as [[press pool]]s to serve more than one news organization (and sometimes a large number of organizations) from a single office. When news sources combine operations following a [[merger]] or other [[Consolidation (business)|business consolidation]], the surviving company often combines or eliminates redundant bureaux. Growing [[multiculturalism]] has facilitated this process: rather than demanding a reporter from their own country or locale who has been sent on assignment, news audiences have come to tolerate or even expect to see stories in remote locations covered by people who live locally; this empowers the audience to make their own judgments about any apparent cultural difference between themselves and the news subjects, rather than leaving the function of cultural interpretation entirely up to the reporter.
The often-criticized practice of [[parachute journalism]] allows [[News media]] to cover stories remotely using journalists who are generalists rather than more specialized field experts. Rather than leaving journalists in place waiting for breaking news to occur, smaller staff can be assigned as needed to wherever there are breaking stories, either by commuting to the physical location or by synthesizing reports from remote sources. An even more controversial practice, sometimes described as a reaction to declining resources rather than a legitimate cost-saving measure, is to rely on and reprint information from [[press release]]s written by [[public relations]] professionals working for people or companies that are the subject of an article, or have an interest in an article, without spending the resources to verify or conduct independent research on the matter. Another practice that limits news bureaux is [[embedded reporter|embedded reporting]], whereby [[war correspondent]]s travel under the care of military units rather than at their own direction. The ability to quickly and safely travel throughout a war zone, and to obtain interviews with soldiers and coverage of important conflicts, appeals to news media, but at the cost of journalistic independence and, according to some, objectivity.
==Nontraditional bureaux==
The interaction between professional journalists, witnesses, and news subjects has evolved considerably. Whereas news subjects and bystanders were once treated simply as [[witnesses]] to be interviewed for a [[news story]], media have now accepted them as part of the news process. There are many antecedents to [[Citizen journalism]]. For example, meteorologists would count on amateurs to gather weather data to report, or interview willing subjects unrelated to a news story for "[[man on the street]]" interviews. As early as the 1930s the [[Soviet Union]] encouraged millions of amateur [[People's correspondent]]s to expose corruption and otherwise report on news.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-14|publisher=Moscow Times|date= July 3, 2006|title=Proletarian Bloggers Celebrate a Milestone|author=Carl Schreck|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/stories/2006/07/03/002.html}}</ref> Beginning in the 1970s, media, unable to respond quickly enough to obtain compelling coverage of natural disasters and weather phenomena such as [[tornadoes]] would count on hobbyists for photographs and film footage. With improvements in technology and as [[video camera]]s and [[Videophone|video-equipped cell phone]]s became widely available, they set up formal programs to gather material from nonprofessionals. For example, in August, 2006, [[CNN]] launched "CNN Exchange", by which the public is encouraged to submit "I-Reports" comprising photographs, videos, or news accounts.<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-13|publisher=C/Net|title=CNN snatching page out of YouTube's book|author=Greg Sandoval|date=July 30, 2006|url=http://www.news.com/2100-1025-6100139.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel|accessdate=2007-11-14|title=CNN welcoming citizen journalists|author=Scott Leith|date=August 1, 2006|url=http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=478319}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> More recently newspapers have incorporated [[blogs]], once seen as a threat to conventional news practice, either by creating blogs of their own (and deputizing local or field-specific bloggers as a second, lower-paid tier among their recognized staff of [[independent contractor]]s) or by covering blogs as news sources.
In 2006 [[Reuters]] opened its first virtual news Bureau, staffing real-life reporters in a virtual office in [[Second Life]].<ref>{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-14|publisher=USA Today|title=Reuters opens virtual news bureau in 'Second Life'|date=October 10, 2006|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2006-10-16-reuters-second-life_x.htm?POE=TECISVA}}</ref> [[CNN]] followed suit in October 2007, but took a citizen journalism approach, allowing residents of Second Life to submit their own reportage.<ref name="mw">{{cite news|accessdate=2007-11-14 |publisher=Media Week |title=CNN To Launch Bureau in Second Life Virtual World |author=Mike Shields |date=October 29, 2007 |url=http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/news/recent_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003664297 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031060212/http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/news/recent_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003664297 |archivedate=2007-10-31 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Although the news audience of Second World is relatively small, and declining, media consider it a training ground for themselves and participants, applicable to future virtual news projects.<ref name="mw"/>

[[File:Battle of Rio Nunez 1849.jpg|thumb|Belgian and French warships during the Rio Nuñez Incident by [[Paul Jean Clays]]]]{{Expand Dutch|date=July 2018}} The '''Rio Nuñez incident''' or '''Rio Nuñez affair''' was an [[international incident]] which occurred on the [[Nunez river|Rio Nuñez]] near [[Boké]], in modern-day [[Guinea]], in 1849. The incident occurred when vessels of a joint [[Belgium|Belgian]] and [[French Second Empire|French]] naval force fired on two [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] traders in the area.
During the 1840s and 50s, [[West Africa]] was the site of fledgling colonial rivalry between European powers. The Nuñez region lay between the [[French conquest of Senegal|French colony of Senegal]] and [[Gambia Colony and Protectorate|British Gambia]] and [[Sierra Leone]]. French traders were increasingly challenged by commercial trading expeditions from Britain, Belgium and America.
The French regional commander, [[Louis Édouard Bouët-Willaumez|Édouard Bouët-Willaumez]], hoped that the Nuñez region could be formally annexed as a protectorate of the [[French colonial empire]]. The attack, far from securing the region for France, went contrary to Bouët-Willaumez's plans. Both France and Belgium led a [[cover-up]]. Attempts by the British Prime Minister, [[Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston|Viscount Palmerston]], to force France to pay reparations for the incident were ultimately unsuccessful and the affair lasted four years.
The incident formed part of the "Prelude to the [[Scramble for Africa]]" and, as Bouët-Willaumez had hoped, did lead to increased French control of the Nuñez. In 1866, French forces occupied Boké. The affair was therefore one of the first signs of future French hegemony in West Africa in what would become [[French West Africa]] (AOF).

{{italic title}} {{Distinguish|The Sound of Music Live!}} '''''The Sound of Music Live''''' is a [[television special]] that was originally broadcast by [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] on 20 December 2015. The special was an adaptation of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s Broadway musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'', starring [[Kara Tointon]] as [[Maria von Trapp]], performed and televised [[live television|live]] from [[3 Mills Studios]] in London.
On 9 November 2018, the production was broadcast in the United States as part of [[PBS]]'s performing arts anthology series ''[[Great Performances]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.unionleader.com/great-performances-imports-uk-s-sound-of-music/article_f1a6feb2-4b7f-57f9-9a41-e05aa84a76de.html|title='Great Performances' imports UK's 'Sound of Music'|work=UnionLeader.com|access-date=2018-11-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Production == In October 2015, ITV announced that it would transmit a live adaptation of the musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' as part of its holiday programming lineup, in what would be the first time that such a programme had been attempted in the United Kingdom.<ref name="deadline-itvsom">{{cite web|title=ITV To Mount ‘The Sound Of Music Live!’ UK Christmas Special|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/itv-sound-of-music-live-christmas-special-kara-tointon-1201590814/|website=Deadline.com|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref> ''The Sound of Music Live'' was part of ITV's continuing efforts to broadcast more live "[[Event television|event]]" programs, which are designed to attract critical masses of viewers by encouraging them to watch via the original broadcast, rather than via [[video on demand|catch-up]] services and [[digital video recorder]]s. The desire for increased ITV viewership came especially in the wake of declining ratings for its reality music competition ''[[The X Factor (UK)|The X Factor]]'', whose [[The X Factor (UK series 12)|series 12]] finale had the second-smallest viewership in the programme's history. ITV had similarly broadcast live episodes of its series ''[[Coronation Street]]'' in [[Coronation Street Live (2000 episode)|2000]] and [[Coronation Street Live (2010 episode)|2010]] in honour of its 40th and 50th anniversary respectively, and in 2015 for ITV's 60th anniversary.<ref name="deadline-itvsom"/>
This was not the first time that ''The Sound of Music'' had been adapted in such a manner. In 2013, U.S. network [[NBC]] broadcast its own [[The Sound of Music Live!|live television adaptation of ''The Sound of Music'']] starring [[country music|country]] singer [[Carrie Underwood]]; similarly to ITV's version, it was an adaptation of the original musical, and not based on the [[The Sound of Music|film version]]. Although it received mixed reviews, it was seen by over 18 million viewers. As follow-ups, NBC produced similar adaptations of ''[[Peter Pan Live!|Peter Pan]]'' and ''[[The Wiz Live!|The Wiz]]'' in 2014 and 2015 respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/the-wiz-live-nbc-s-latest-live-musical-broadcast-from-long-island-1.11164689|title=‘The Wiz Live!’: NBC’s latest live musical broadcast from Long Island|last1=Crook|first1=John|date=26 November 2015|website=newsday.com |publisher=Newsday|access-date=26 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://tvline.com/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-ratings-nbc/ |title=Ratings: NBC's Sound of Music Live! Does Something Very Good; Glee and Grey's Eye Lows |last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TVLine |accessdate=December 7, 2013}}</ref> Creative director [[Coky Giedroyc]] stated that ITV's iteration would be a "whole different animal" in comparison to NBC's, explaining that she wanted to "keep it true to the original", and maintain a focus on the political aspects of the story.<ref name="rt-differences">{{cite web|title=How will The Sound of Music Live work?|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-12-20/how-will-the-sound-of-music-live-work|website=Radio Times|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="guardian-future">{{cite web|last1=Martinson|first1=Jane|title=As ITV prepares for the Sound of Music Live, are we watching TV's future?| url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/dec/15/as-itv-prepares-for-the-sound-of-music-live-are-we-watching-tvs-future|website=The Guardian|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> The production was conducted on soundstages at [[3 Mills Studios]] in London, with the sets alone having a budget of nearly £750,000.<ref name="rt-differences"/>
==Cast== [[Kara Tointon]] played Maria, and [[Julian Ovenden]] played Captain Georg von Trapp. The supporting cast included veterans of British television and theatre, including [[Alexander Armstrong]] as Max Detweiler, [[Katherine Kelly (actress)|Katherine Kelly]] as Baroness Elsa Schraeder, [[Maria Friedman]] as Mother Abess, [[Evelyn Hoskins]] as Liesl von Trapp, Jon Tarcy as Rolf Gruber, [[Mel Giedroyc]] as the housekeeper, Frau Schmidt, and [[Paul Copley]] as the butler, Franz.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sound of Music Live!|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/episode/dwnsbw/the-sound-of-music-live|website=Radio Times|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== ''The Sound of Music Live'' received mixed reviews. Mark Shenton of ''[[The Stage]]'' said it was a failed experiment, with "uninspired and sometimes insipid" choreography and direction, although he praised the cast's performances.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shenton|first1=Mark|title=The Sound of Music Live review – ‘bold experiment doesn’t pay off’|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2015/the-sound-of-music-live-review-bold-experiment-doesnt-pay-off/|website=The Stage|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> Claire Allfree of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said it lacked both the intimacy of live theatre and the scope of the big screen, but nevertheless judged it "more a success than it was a failure," saying that former ''[[EastEnders]]'' star Tointon "brought a refreshing earthiness and grit to Maria that made the passionate, unconventional novice feel thoroughly modern and accessible."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sound of Music Live, review: 'much to enjoy'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/12056862/the-sound-of-music-review-kara-tointon-live-itv.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> ''[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]'' said that Tointon was "showered with praise" for her performance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kara Tointon shocks fans with incredible vocals as she plays Maria in The Sound Of Music live|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/kara-tointon-shocks-fans-incredible-7048037|website=The Mirror|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>
The programme was watched by over 3.82 million viewers according to overnight ratings figures, being beaten by the [[The Apprentice (UK series eleven)|series eleven]] finale of ''[[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' (5.31 million) and its lead-in, the [[2015 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award|BBC Sports Personality of the Year]] presentation (5.78 million).<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/the-apprentice/news/a777848/uk-tv-ratings-the-apprentice-final-loses-800000-from-last-year-sports-personality-is-top-with-57m/ |title=UK TV ratings: The Apprentice final is lowest in 10 years, Sports Personality is top with 5.7m |author=Tom Eames |work=Digital Spy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ITV's The Sound of Music Live draws 4m viewers|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/itvs-the-sound-of-music-live-draws-4m-viewers/|website=The Stage|accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox concert | concert_name = This Is It | image = This Is It Michael Jackson banner.png | image_size = 220px | caption = | artist = [[Michael Jackson]] | type = | venue = | tour = | album = ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'' | start_date = July 13, 2009 | end_date = March 6, 2010 | number_of_legs = 2 | number_of_shows = 50 (cancelled) | duration = | support_act = | attendance = | gross = | website = {{URL|www.michaeljacksonlive.com|Official website}} | last_concert = [[Michael Jackson: Live at the Apollo 2002]]
(2002) | this_concert = '''This Is It'''
(2009–10) | Misc = }} '''This Is It''' was a planned [[concert residency]] by [[Michael Jackson]] which was scheduled to begin in July 2009 and end September 29, 2009 with a second leg which was scheduled to run from January 2010 through March 2010 with a total of 50 shows.https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010-20090312 Jackson announced This Is It at a press conference in the [[The O2 Arena|O2 Arena]], stating that it would be his final series of concerts in London. [[AEG Live]], the concert promoters, released a promotional video that took up an entire commercial break, setting a record for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. Initially, only 10 concerts were announced, but following public demand, 40 more concerts were added. Ticket sales broke several records and Jackson's album sales increased following the announcement; AEG Live estimated that the first 10 dates alone would have earned Jackson approximately £50 million. In preparation for the concert series, Jackson had been collaborating with high-profile figures including fashion designer [[Christian Audigier]], choreographer [[Kenny Ortega]] and bodybuilder [[Lou Ferrigno]]. Prior to Jackson's death in 2009, Allgood Entertainment sued Jackson for $40 million, claiming that he had breached an exclusivity agreement with them by agreeing to the This Is It concerts; the case was dismissed. After Jackson's death, AEG Live offered either refunds to ticket holders or a special "souvenir" ticket designed by Jackson. The cancelled shows, record-breaking ticket sales{{cite web |first=Daniel|last=Kreps |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/03/12/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010/ |title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7941221.stm |agency=BBC News |title= Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher= ''[[BBC]]''|date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=BBC staff }}{{cite web |url= http://www.livedaily.com/news/18434.html |author= The Livedaily Staff |work= [[LiveDaily]] |title= Michael Jackson breaking records with 50-show run in London |date= March 9, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100209062136/http://livedaily.com/news/18434.html |archivedate= February 9, 2010 |df= mdy-all }} and potential for a world tour{{cite web |url= http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/entertainment/6405947/australia-part-of-planned-jackson-tour/ |title= Australia part of planned world tour |publisher=[[Yahoo! 7]] |date= October 30, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=Australia |first=Yahoo }}{{cite web |url= http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1624853/20091027/story.jhtml?rsspartner=rssColdFusion |author= The MTV Staff |work= MTV |title= This Is It Director Kenny Ortega On Michael Jackson's Final Rehearsals |date= November 5, 2009 |accessdate= September 23, 2009}} led to This Is It being termed "the greatest concert[s] that never happened."{{cite web |first=IGN |last=Staff |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/101/1016381p1.html|title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''IGN'' |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.michaeljackson.com/ru/this-is-it|title=''Jackson's This Is It This Fall'' | publisher=[[Sony]] |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009|first=Sony |last=Staff}} [[Columbia Pictures]] acquired the footage of the rehearsals and released a [[concert film]], ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]],'' accompanied by a [[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|compilation album of the same name]]. ==Promotion and significance== {{Wikinews|Michael Jackson to make last public concerts}} Jackson announced the first 10 performances during a press conference at the O2 Arena on March 5, 2009. As many as 7,000 fans and 350 reporters awaited Jackon's arrival, many donning Jackson-related clothing.{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/100481-jackson-set-to-announce-shows|title=Jackson set to announce shows|publisher=MTV|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news |last= Akbar |first=Arifa |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/jacko-on-tour-this-will-be-the-final-curtain-call-i-love-you-i-love-you-all-1638497.html|title=Jacko on tour: 'This will be the final curtain call. I love you, I love you all' – News, Music |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} He commented at the conference, "I just wanted to say that these will be my final show performances in London. When I say this is it, it really means this is it", adding that it was his "final curtain call", although he may have just been referring to performing in London. Organizers touted the residency as, "dramatic shows [that] promise an explosive return with a band of the highest calibre, a state-of-the-art stage show and incredible surprise [[support act]]s".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4944927/Michael-Jackson-announces-comeback-gigs.html |title=Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 |last= Khan|first=Urmee | location=London}} Hours before the press conference, promotional posters for the residency were displayed around London. Further promotion took up an entire [[commercial break]] period on [[ITV London]] during ''[[Dancing on Ice (Series 4)|Dancing on Ice]]'', the first time this has ever happened for a musical artist. The advert, which cost £1 million to air, was viewed by 11 million people. {{cite web |last=Griffin|first=Zoe |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/04/michael-jackson-has-50-medical-tests-to-prove-he-can-manage-02-arena-dates-115875-21171604/|title=Michael Jackson has 50 medical tests to prove he can manage 02 Arena dates |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7925388.stm|title= 'Final curtain call' for Jackson|publisher=BBC|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Youngs |first=Ian }} {{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/News/MostEmailed/888126/Michael-Jackson-takes-entire-three-half-minute-ITV-ad-slot/ |title=Michael Jackson takes entire three and a half minute ITV ad slot |publisher=www.mediaweek.co.uk|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Barnett|first=Emma }}{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/09/michael-jackson-live-dates-ad-during-dancing-on-ice-seen-by-11m-fans-115875-21184002/|title=Michael Jackson live dates ad during Dancing On Ice seen by 11m fans|publisher=''Daily Mirror''|date=March 9, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2009}} The shows, Jackson's first significant concert events since the [[Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Celebration]] in 2001, had been cited as one of the year's most important musical events,{{cite news|first=Rosie|last=Swash|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/mar/05/michael-jackson-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson can't fail to sell out the O2 arena|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} and as the greatest comeback in the history of pop.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1151504/Michael-Jackson-chooses-Londons-O2-arena-greatest-comeback-history.html|author=Simon Cable |work=[[Dailymail.co.uk]] |title=Michael Jackson chooses London's O2 arena for the 'greatest comeback in history'|date=November 5, 2009 |accessdate=February 21, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43249|title=Michael Jackson announces O2 Arena London gigs — and retirement?|publisher=''[[NME]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Randy Phillips, president and chief executive of [[AEG Live]], stated that the first 10 dates would earn Jackson approximately £50 million (about US$80.1 million).{{cite news|first=Patrick |last= Foster |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article5854735.ece|title=Michael Jackson grand finale curtain-raiser|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' characterized the concerts as an "astonishing comeback for a man who in recent years has been dogged by controversy", adding that Jackson still had "enormous commercial clout". The ''[[Evening Standard]]'' stated that the deal was the "showbiz coup of the decade" for AEG Live, while ''[[The Independent]]'' remarked that the finalized 50 concerts would provide London with a "much-needed" economic boost.{{cite web |first=Amar |last=Singh |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23661911-details/Detoxing+brand+Jacko/article.do |title=Detoxing Brand Jacko |publisher=''[[Evening Standard]]'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/the-barometer-michael-jackson-angela-gheorghiu-horne-and-corden-madonna-in-fancy-dress-1649091.html |title=The Barometer: Michael Jackson; Angela Gheorghiu; Horne and Corden; Madonna in fancy dress |publisher=''The Independent'' |date=March 20, 2009 |accessdate=March 25, 2009 | location=London}} Joe Cohen, chief executive of [[Seatwave]], told [[BBC 6 Music]] that the shows would generate £1 billion for the economy.{{cite web |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/music/article.html?Michael_Jackson_in_billion_pound_boost_to_economy&in_article_id=652877&in_page_id=25 |title=Michael Jackson in 'billion pound' boost to economy |publisher=''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]'' |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} ==Public interest== [[File:O2 with Canary Wharf and City of London (15007282651).jpg|right|thumb|250px|The O2 Arena, where the concerts would have been held]] Some websites offered early tickets, which the [[Association of Secondary Ticket Agents]] warned were fake. "We are warning people not to buy tickets that are not yet on sale because it is unlikely that they will receive those tickets", announced the organization's chief, Graham Burns. He concluded, "It's impossible when the dates haven't been announced to be selling tickets for something when there are no announced dates".{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43235|title=Michael Jackson London 02 Arena ticket warning issued|publisher=''NME''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Jackson's official website allowed fans to register early for a "pre-sale" draw. Some fans had difficulty applying, as the website could not deal with the large number of registrations—reportedly up to 16,000 applications a second.{{cite news |first=Matthew|last=Moore|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4945911/Michael-Jackson-O2-ticket-website-attracting-16000-visits-a-second.html|title=Michael Jackson O2 ticket website attracting 16,000 visits a second |publisher=''The Daily Telegraph'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} In the space of 24 hours, nearly a million people from around the world registered for pre-sale tickets, enough to fill the venue 50 times over.{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/06/michael-jackson-adds-10-more-dates-to-comeback-tour-115875-21177334/|title=Michael Jackson adds 10 more dates to comeback tour |publisher=''Daily Mirror'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/102275-michael-jackson-announces-dates |title=Michael Jackson Announces Dates |publisher=MTV |date=March 10, 2009 |accessdate=March 29, 2009 }} Tickets that had not even been printed were selling on auction website [[eBay]] for £300.{{cite news|first=Elizabeth |last=Day |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/08/michael-jackson-profile-pop-culture |title=Off the wall but still invincible |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=March 8, 2009 | location=London}} Sales of Jackson's albums increased following the press conference. Overnight, sales of ''[[Off the Wall]]'' rose 200%, ''[[Bad (album)|Bad]]'' rose 110%, ''[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]]'' rose 165% and ''[[Thriller 25]]'' rose 155%.* {{cite web |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |title=Jacko's album sales are backo|date=March 7, 2009 |publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310080317/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |archive-date=March 10, 2009 |dead-url=yes}} The two-day pre-sale began on March 11, and 40 extra dates were added to meet high demand—five of these dates were reserved in their entirety for the public sale. More than 1.5  million fans caused two sites offering pre-sale tickets to crash within minutes of going online.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23660868-details/1.5m+fans+crash+sites+in+rush+for+Jacko+gig/article.do |title=1.5m fans crash sites in rush for Jacko gig |publisher=''Evening Standard'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 }} In the space of two hours, 190,000 tickets were sold.{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Cable |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1161160/Fans-fury-touts-sell-Michael-Jackson-concert-tickets-16-000-pair-black-market.html |title=Fans' fury as touts sell Michael Jackson concert tickets for up to £16,000 a pair on black market |publisher=''Daily Mail'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 | location=London}} Two million people tried to buy pre-sale tickets in the space of 18 hours.{{cite news |first=David |last=Miranda |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25175199-5006024,00.html |title=Michael Jackson doubles London shows after 2 million seek tickets |publisher=''[[Herald Sun]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Veronica Schmidt of ''[[The Times]]'' stated of the reception, "Michael Jackson has floored his critics",{{cite news |first=Veronica |last=Schmidt |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article5889522.ece |title=Michael Jackson sells out London concerts and adds more shows |publisher=''The Times'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} while organizers proclaimed it a "cultural phenomenon".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7940515.stm |title=Jackson to play 50 gigs at the O2 |publisher=BBC |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} It was announced that Jackson would break the record for number of shows performed by an artist at a single venue, which had been set by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], who hosted a residency at the same arena for his [[21 Nights in London: The Earth Tour]] concerts. According to Jackson's website, the following records were or would have been broken: "The biggest audience ever to see an artist in one city", "The greatest number of people to attend a series of arena shows", "The fastest ticket sales in history". Randy Phillips acknowledged that Jackson could have sold out even more dates, but this would have conflicted with other career plans.{{cite web |first=Ray |last=Waddell |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269213/update-michael-jackson-up-to-50-london-shows |title=Update: Michael Jackson Up To 50 London Shows |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} On March 13, the other 50% of seats for dates 1–45 and all the seats for dates 46–50 went on sale to the general public. Within four hours, all 50 dates had sold out.* {{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |title=Jackson's Tears Of Joy As O2 Shows Sell Out |date=March 13, 2009 |publisher=[[Sky News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316004206/https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |archive-date=March 16, 2009 |dead-url=yes}}} At this stage, the sales of ''[[King of Pop (album)|King of Pop]]'' were up 400% and the sales of ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]'' were up 200%.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/03/13/michael.jackson.concerts.tickets/ |title=750,000 tickets for Jackson concerts sell in 4 hours |publisher=CNN |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Tickets appeared on eBay for as much as £10,000.{{cite news |first=Rosie |last=Swash |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/13/michael-jackson-o2-arena-residency-sells-out |title=Michael Jackson's 50 dates at London's O2 arena sell out |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} ==Preparation and concert details== The 50-concert run was originally scheduled to start on July 8, 2009 and conclude on February 24, 2010.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8060282.stm |title=Jackson delays opening tour dates |publisher=BBC |date=May 20, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} Each of the shows would have been performed at the O2 Arena in London, which has a capacity of 23,000.{{cite web|first=Andre|last=Paine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269278/michael-jackson-says-london-concerts-to-be-final-curtain-call|title=Michael Jackson Says London Concerts To Be 'Final Curtain Call'|publisher=''Billboard''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} New York-based fashion designer [[Zaldy]] served as head costumer, creating ten of Jackson's stage looks while the other six were created by his longtime costumers, Michael Bush and Dennis Tompkins. Jay Ruckel from La Crasia Gloves recreated Jackson's iconic single glove for the concerts.{{cite news |first=William |last=Sherman |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/06/14/2009-06-14_theyre_still_proudly_making_it_in_nyc_manufacturing_alive__well_at_feisty_factor.html |title=Michael Jackson, Hubble Telescope draw from New York manufacturing |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' |date=June 14, 2009|accessdate=June 20, 2009}} The costumes he was to wear during the shows were encrusted with 300,000 [[Swarovski crystals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/45530|title=Extra Michael Jackson O2 Arena tickets made available|date=June 23, 2009|publisher=NME|accessdate=June 26, 2009}} In April 2009, thousands of dancers flew in from all around the world to audition from the 13th to the 15th for Jackson, who helped select the 11 finalists in person.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268649/michael-jackson-rehearsals-move-forward |title=Michael Jackson Rehearsals Move Forward |publisher=Billboard |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} [[Kenny Ortega]], who had collaborated with Jackson previously, was to work on the overall design and direction of concerts. Ortega said that the final product would have been a "theatrical musical experience".{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-Auditions-Dancers-For-Tour-And-Works-With-Director/Article/200905215280285 |title=Michael Jackson Gets Ready For Tour |publisher=Sky News |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44599 |title=Michael Jackson enlists 'High School Musical' director for London O2 shows |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jacksons-Comeback-Tour-12-Dancers-Picked-To-Join-Singer-On-Stage-At-Londons-O2-Aena/Article/200905315284334 |title=This Is It: Jacko Picks Comeback Gig Dancers |publisher=Sky News |date=May 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} According to Randy Philips, £13 million was to be spent on producing the concerts, which would have included 18–22 songs and 22 different sets. There also would have been [[Aerial dance|aerial dancing]] similar to routines by [[Cirque du Soleil]]. Carla Ferrigno told [[Reuters]] that [[Lou Ferrigno|her husband Lou]] had been helping Jackson train in advance of the shows. Jackson and Ferrigno had previously worked together.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Dobuzinskis |url=http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |title=The Hulk trains Michael Jackson ahead of London concerts |publisher=Reuters |date=June 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621224923/http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |archivedate=June 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} On May 20, it was announced that the first concert would be pushed back five days to July 13 and three other July dates would be rescheduled for March 2010. AEG Live said that the delay was necessary because more time was needed for dress rehearsals. The revised schedule called for 27 shows between July 13 and September 29, 2009, followed by a three-month break, before resuming in the new year with 23 more shows between January 7 and March 6, 2010. Some fans petitioned for the reversal of AEG Live's decision.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44820 |title=Michael Jackson fans launch petition over O2 Arena postponement |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 21, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} In late June, several hundred seats for each of the dates were put on sale. These seats were held back until production logistics were worked out.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8115638.stm |title=More Jackson tickets up for sale |publisher=BBC |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 }} It was suggested that after the London concerts, Jackson might head to [[Australia]], [[Europe]], [[India]], [[China]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Japan]] before moving on to North America. Randy Phillips, the CEO of [[AEG Live]], told The LA Times that Australia was part of Michael Jackson's international tour plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |title=Michael Jackson Planning Australian Tour Before His Death |publisher=Take 40 |date=June 28, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504000236/http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |archivedate=May 4, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} According to Jermaine Jackson's 2011 book ''You Are Not Alone: Michael Through a Brother's Eyes'', after the London concerts were finished, Jackson was planning to extend his deal with AEG Live which included new music, a potential three-picture movie deal, a series of one-off concert dates starting in China, a halftime slot at one of the future [[Super Bowl]] games to surpass his own halftime show at the [[Super Bowl XXVII]] in January 1993 and two more tours (one of which was to be a final reunion with his brothers based on a promise made to their [[Katherine Jackson|mother]] to see her sons perform together one last time before she passed away). After the deal was completed, he planned to take time off from musical entertainment and move on to (possibly) directing his own film ideas, such as making a feature-length motion picture based on his 1982 song "Thriller" and [[Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)|the music video of the same name]]. It was also later revealed that [http://www.damienshields.com/michael-jacksons-halloween-special-that-never-was/ a yearly Halloween television special] based on his horror-themed songs, such as "Thriller" and "Ghosts", was part of Jackson's deal with AEG Live. In [[Trial of Conrad Murray|Conrad Murray's manslaughter trial]], David Walgren stated another one of Jackson's future plans was to open a children's hospital. This was heard in an audio tape Conrad Murray played of Jackson under the influence of propofol on May 10, 2009. His voice is barely recognisable in the recording, but he can be clearly heard saying that he wanted to build the greatest children's hospital in the world and name it after himself: The ''Michael Jackson's Children's Hospital''. Walgren also stated that while the tour was happening, Jackson wanted to buy an estate with streams, horses and animals so his three children, Prince, Paris and Blanket could live normal lives as their father performed the concerts, as he was photographed looking for a house in the United Kingdom with his children. Walgren also said that the tour would begin that summer, and Jackson could take his children out of school and bring them with him so they could see him perform in London. ===Songs prepared=== As shown in ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]'', songs prepared for the concerts included "[[Wanna Be Startin' Somethin']]", "[[Jam (song)|Jam]]", "[[They Don't Care About Us]]", "[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]", "[[Smooth Criminal]]", "[[The Way You Make Me Feel]]", a medley of songs by [[The Jackson 5]] consisting of "[[I Want You Back]]", "[[The Love You Save]]", "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]" and "[[Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)]]", "[[I Just Can't Stop Loving You]]", "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]", "[[Beat It]]", "[[Black or White]]", "[[Earth Song]]", "[[Billie Jean]]", and "[[Man in the Mirror]]". Later on, "[[Stranger in Moscow]]", "[[You Are Not Alone]]", "[[Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough]]", "[[Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)|Rock with You]]", "[[Dirty Diana]]" ,"[[You Rock My World]]", "[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson song)|Dangerous]]", "[[We Are the World]]", "[[Heal the World]]" and "[[Will You Be There]]" were also confirmed to have been planned for the shows. Due to the larger than usual roster of songs, as well as time constraints, Jackson would perform some songs with one verse less than he did in previous tours (such as "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'", "Jam", "The Way You Make Me Feel" and "Black or White"). "[[Bad (Michael Jackson song)|Bad]]" was rumored to have been reserved for select concerts. On the final dates, Jackson wanted to perform a ballad called "River Ripple", written by him, with an African choir and his children. During the final concert before "Man in the Mirror", Michael was slated to premiere a song called "Best of Joy", written and recorded in 2009 prior to Jackson's death. As of 2018, the full version of "River Ripple" remains unreleased (although snippets of the song have leaked on YouTube), while "Best of Joy" was officially released in 2010 on Jackson's first Timor Dance) {{col-3}} ;Production and other personnel *[[Kenny Ortega]] – show direction *Alif Sankey – [[Assistant producer|associate production]] *Michael Cotten – [[Production designer|production design]] *Michael Curry – production design *Michael Jackson & [[Travis Payne]] – [[choreography]] *Stacy Walker – choreography assistance *Tony Testa – choreography assistance *Patrick Woodroffe – [[Lighting designer|lighting design]] *[[David Elsewhere]] – dance coaching *Shahzad Perez - Specialty Act *Gregg Smith – [[Casting (performing arts)|casting direction]] *Karen Faye Heinze – hair and make-up *[[Zaldy Goco]] – [[Costume designer|chief of costume design]] *Michael Bush – [[Costume designer|costume design]] *Dennis Thompkins - [[Costume designer|costume design]] *[[AEG Live]] – [[Promoter (entertainment)|promotion]] *Dave Polich - synth programming {{col-end}} ==Litigation== In June 2009, concert promoter Allgood Entertainment, represented by Ira Meyerowitz and Jon Kekielek of MJlawfirm, sued Jackson for $40 million. He claimed that Jackson, through his manager [[Frank DiLeo]], had agreed to a single and a $30 million reunion concert with [[The Jackson 5]] and his sister [[Janet Jackson]]. According to the concert promoter, the alleged contractual agreement prevented Jackson from performing elsewhere before the reunion concert and for a three-month period after it. Thus, agreeing to a 50 date residency at the O2 arena was an alleged breach of the Allgood Entertainment contract. The filing company stated that AEG Live knew of the alleged agreement with Jackson and used their dominance in the industry to coerce Jackson into agreeing to the residency.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8094537.stm |title=Jackson sued over reunion concert |publisher=BBC |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jun/12/michael-jackson-sued-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson sued for O2 arena residency|publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/may/12/michael-jackson-comeback-concerts |title=Michael Jackson comeback concerts in jeopardy? |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}} In August 2010, the judge dismissed the case, stating that there was no evidence of a binding agreement, no contracts were signed.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11038050 | work=BBC News | title=Judge dismisses Jackson reunion claim | date=August 20, 2010}} The case was in limbo as of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://archive.recapthelaw.org/nysd/347380/ |title=AllGood Entertainment, Inc. et al v. Jackson et al (nysd/347380) – The RECAP Archive |publisher=Archive.recapthelaw.org |date= |accessdate=May 6, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Yazmeen |url=http://muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-patrick-allocco.html |title=Interview with Patrick Allocco- President of AllGood Entertainment ~ LET'S CALL SPADE A SPADE |publisher=Muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com |date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=May 6, 2013}} ==Jackson's death and refunds== {{Further|Death of Michael Jackson}} On June 25, 2009, Jackson died after going into [[cardiac arrest]] which was caused by an overdose of [[Propofol]] and [[Benzodiazepine|benzodiazepines]], eighteen days before his planned first show. AEG Live, who persuaded Jackson to sign up for the shows, faced a liability of up to £300 million and an empty venue for the next nine months.{{cite news|last=Sherwin|first=Adam|title=O2 arena counts cost as curtain closes on the greatest show of all|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6580748.ece|publisher=The Times|date=June 26, 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2009 | location=London}} The O2 arena stated that full refunds, including all ticket service charges, would be available to those who purchased tickets through authorized agents, but that "fans will have the option to be sent the actual tickets they would have received to attend the shows in lieu of the full refunds which are being offered."{{cite web |title=UCLA Statement — Michael Jackson|url=http://www.theo2.co.uk/inside/ucla-statement-michael-jackson.html |publisher=[[The O2 Arena]] |accessdate=July 1, 2009}} Fans who bought their tickets from private sellers potentially faced difficulties. eBay recommended that purchasers contact their sellers for refunds and stated that those who used PayPal can get their money back if the purchase was made during the last 45 days,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8120412.stm |title=Refund issues over Jackson gigs |publisher=''BBC News'' |date=June 26, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2009}} then later stated that "all buyers on the site will receive a full refund for their ticket purchase".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8122580.stm |title=eBay will refund Jackson tickets |publisher=BBC News |date=June 27, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2009}} ==Posthumous film and album== {{Further|Michael Jackson's This Is It|Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)}} Following Jackson's death, AEG stated that they had over "100 hours of footage of preparations and rehearsals for the shows".{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32360110 |title=Judge OKs Jackson performance film deal |agency=Associated Press |work=[[MSNBC|MSNBC.com]] |date=August 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}} On August 10, 2009, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Mitchell Beckloff approved a deal between film distributor [[Columbia Pictures]] and AEG Live for the former company to purchase and distribute rehearsal footage of Jackson for a film entitled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/showbiz/2009-08/06/content_8532737.htm |title=Michael Jackson film deal outlined in court papers |work=ChinaDaily.com |date=August 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-jackson11-2009aug11,0,2938755.story |author=Christopher Smith |work=[[LA Times|LA Times.com]] |title=Sony Pictures to produce Michael Jackson film |accessdate=September 21, 2009 | date=August 11, 2009}} According to court documents, Columbia paid $60 million (£35 million) for rights to the rehearsal footage.{{cite web |url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/michael_jackson/news/13441 |title=Michael jackson This Is It film deal agreed |work=Uncut.co.uk |date=August 8, 2009|accessdate=October 3, 2009}} The papers filed in court had reportedly stated that Jackson's estate will get 90% of the profits and that AEG Live will get the remaining 10% from the film's revenue.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/aug/11/michael-jackson-film-october-release |author=Rosie Swash |title=Michael Jackson film gets October release date |work=[[Guardian.co.uk]] |date=August 11, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009 | location=London}} The film was directed by [[Kenny Ortega]] who was also the director of the live concert. It was compiled mostly from footage that was shot as reference for production discussions and was never meant to be shown publicly. Some of the music and vocals in the film were added from previous recordings, though most were from the live performance. The film was released on October 28, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |title=This Is It Worldwide Release Dates |work=[[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures.com]] |accessdate=September 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922214515/http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |archivedate=September 22, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} An accompanying album to the film was also released. Titled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'', the compilation was distributed internationally on October 26, and to North America the following day. The two-disc album features music "inspired from the documentary of the same name".{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/09/the-michael-jackson-new-musical-onslaught-begins.html |author=Chris Lee |title=The Michael Jackson new-music onslaught begins [Updated] |work=[[The LA Times|TheLATimes.com]] |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Of the album, Sony said, "Disc one will feature the original album masters of some of Michael's biggest hits arranged in the same sequence as they appear in the film" and stated that "the disc ends with two versions of the 'never-released' '[[This Is It (Michael Jackson song)|This Is It]]' [...] This song is featured in the film's closing sequence and includes backing vocals by Michael's brothers, [[The Jacksons]] and Alvin Chea of Take 6."{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a178845/new-jackson-single-lp-to-be-released.html?imdb |title=New Jackson single, LP to be released |author=Tim Parks |date=September 23, 2009 |work=[[Digital Spy|Digital Spy.com]] |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Sony added that the second disc will feature previously unreleased versions from Jackson's "catalogue of hits", along with a spoken word [[poem]] entitled "Planet Earth" and a 36-page commemorative booklet with "exclusive photos of Michael from his last rehearsal".{{cite web |url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/2870440_Unreleased_Michael_Jackson_Song_to_be_Revealed|author=The Insider Staff |work=[[The Insider (TV series)|TheInsider.com]] |title=Unreleased Michael Jackson {{Multiple issues| {{Notability|Biographies|date=January 2010}} {{more footnotes|date=May 2010}} {{cleanup|date=January 2010}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2010}} }} '''Tim Soar''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[fashion designer]], [[graphic designer]], [[event planner]] and [[DJ]]. ==Career== Soar began his creative career working with designer [[Neville Brody]] on an interiors project POST Design. This was followed by independent practice as a graphic designer, and then in the design company STAC collaborating with photographer [[Andrew Catlin]]. His work was focussed in music, producing artwork for numerous international record sleeves, publications and campaigns. ==Career as a DJ== While working with Neville Brody, Soar became involved in the music industry and began working as a DJ. Soar had residencies at a number of venues and clubs across London. He was also involved in the writing and arrangement of [[23 Skidoo (band)|23 Skidoo]]'s song ''Just Like Everybody''. He was also part of the band called Toll, which released the album ''Christ Knows'' in 2006. ==Design label== In 2005, Soar launched the Tim Soar design label and this was described as “really well-made menswear that mixes minimalism, sportswear, tailoring, and unusual fabrications.”{{Cite web|url=http://londonfashionweek.co.uk/designers_profile.aspx?DesignerID=1162|title=London Fashion Week - Tim Soar|website=londonfashionweek.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} In an interview, Soar described his foray from music to fashion design with these words:
I felt that I had something to say about modern menswear and that it was time to move on from the flippant to something more serious. I was tired of seeing gimmicky menswear that was badly made and did not fit correctly. I set out to produce clothes that are a synthesis of minimalism and the avant garde made to the highest possible standards.{{Cite web|url=https://www.notjustalabel.com/designer/soar|title=Soar {{!}} NOT JUST A LABEL|website=www.notjustalabel.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}}
The first collection was presented by the London-based B-Store, the second collection by [[Liberty (department store)|Liberty]], and has continued with packed shows at each [[London Fashion Week]] since Spring/Summer 09. His women's wear line debuted in 2011 with a capsule collection for Browns 24. Soar told [[Vogue (British magazine)|British Vogue]] that the concept is womenswear for boyish women.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/tim-soar-launches-womenswear|title=Girls Who Like Boys|last=Alexander|first=Ella|access-date=2018-07-04}} Soar's collections are now available in numerous countries worldwide. ==Music Concrete== Soar is also creative head of Music Concrete, a music consultancy that was established in 1987. It initially catered to the boutique hotel market but has since expanded into launches, fashion, and events.{{Cite web|url=http://musicconcrete.com/about-music-consultancy/|title=Music Concrete: Music consultant for hotels, spas and bars|website=musicconcrete.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-04}} He has worked with many of the leading UK and international fashion designers and design houses, including [[Donna Karen]] [[Prada]], [[Ralph Lauren]], [[Levi's]], [[Fendi]], [[LVMH]], Mathew Williamson, Fendi and Adidas. Through Music Concrete, Soar also collaborated with luxury hotels groups including Schrager Hotels, St. Martin's Lane Hotel, Sanderson, Columbus and Great Eastern. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.soar-london.com/news Tim Soar news] * [http://www.soar-london.com/press Press Articles] * [http://www.londonfashionweek.co.uk/designer_profile.aspx?DesignerID=1162 London Fashion Week Profile] * [http://www.selectism.com/news/2009/08/24/tim-soar-springsummer-2010-preview/ Selectism Review] * [http://www.vogue.co.uk/fashion/show.aspx/full-length-photos/id,8512 Vogue story] * [http://en.sevenload.com/shows/London-Fashion-Week/episodes/7REIq9A-Tim-Soar-backstage-interview-London-Fashion-Week Interview] * [http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/gq-blogs/fashion-shows/entries/090924-tim-soar-springsummer-2010-catwalk.aspx GQ Magazine] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soar, Tim}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English fashion designers]] [[Category:English DJs]] [[Category:Event planners]]

{{Howto|date=December 2014}} '''Unintentional discharge''' is the event of a [[firearm]] discharging (firing) at a time not intended by the user. An unintended discharge may be produced by an incompatibility between firearm design and usage, such as the phenomenon of [[cooking off]] a round in a closed bolt machine gun, a mechanical malfunction as in the case of [[slamfire]] in an automatic weapon, user induced due to training issues or negligence, or a simple accident. The phenomenon has also been defined in the scientific literature as ''an activation of the trigger mechanism that results in an unplanned discharge that is outside of the firearm’s prescribed use''. Where prescribed use refers to departmental policies and laws related to the operation of firearms (O'Neill, 2018).
==Accidental discharge==
An '''accidental discharge''' ('''AD''') may occur when the trigger of the firearm is deliberately pulled for a purpose other than shooting—dry-fire practice, demonstration, or function testing—but ammunition is unintentionally left in the chamber. Unintentionally leaving a firearm loaded is more likely to occur when the individual handling the gun is poorly trained, and perhaps also with removable-magazine-fed firearms (as the magazine may be removed, giving an unloaded appearance even when a round remains chambered—see discussion of magazine-safeties below).
A second common cause of negligent discharges is when the gun-handler places their finger on the trigger before they have decided to shoot. With the finger so positioned, many activities may cause the finger to compress the trigger unintentionally. For example, if one attempts to holster the firearm with finger on trigger, the holster edge will drive the finger onto the trigger, and discharge is likely. If one stumbles or struggles (with an adversary) with finger on trigger, the grasping motion of both hands will likely cause the trigger finger to compress the trigger.
[[Gun safety]] rules recognize the above possibilities, and aim to prevent them. The primary firearm safety rule usually listed by any source is a version of "Always keep the gun pointed in safe direction."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Izak|first1=Shultz|title=Gun Safe Reviews|url=http://www.shootingandsafety.com/best-gun-safe-reviews/|website=Shooting & Safety|accessdate=23 February 2017|date=26 August 2015}}</ref> Following this rule ensures that, should an accidental discharge occur, no harm will be done. Second, one's finger should remain outside the trigger guard until the decision has been made to fire the weapon; even if (some would say especially if) one is facing a hostile adversary and has to be prepared to fire at a moment's notice, keeping the finger out of the trigger-guard until one has decided to shoot will prevent an accidental shooting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.backwoodshome.com/articles2/ayoob103.html|title=The subtleties of safe firearms handling|last=Ayoob|first=Massad|date=February 2007|website=Issue #103|publisher=Backwoods Home Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
When a firearm is not in use, storing it unloaded and in a separate container from ammunition may also help prevent accidental discharges, especially if the stored firearm is "accessed" by an unauthorized user.
On occasion, an accidental discharge can occur by means other than the finger pulling the [[trigger (firearms)|trigger]], such as dropping a loaded weapon. Because of this possibility, most currently produced pistols are designed with a "drop-safety" or [[Safety (firearms)#Firing pin block|firing pin block]], a mechanism inhibiting or isolating the firing pin, preventing accidental discharge if the firearm is dropped. However, most long guns do not have drop-safeties.
Prevention of dropped-firearm ADs with long guns therefore depends on the user being familiar with the precautions needed for that particular gun: it is standard practice for all long-gun users to unload the firearm's chamber before any activity that might foreseeably result in a dropped firearm (e.g., climbing a fence while hunting), and before placing the firearm in a vehicle (where sudden deceleration may cause the firearm to act as if dropped).
Accidental discharges not involving trigger-pull can also occur if the firearm is mechanically unsound: poor maintenance, abuse, inept "gunsmithing," or the use of substandard materials or defective [[ammunition]] in the gun may all lead to breakage.
In World War II, early versions of the British [[Sten gun]] were notorious for accidentally discharging when dropped. While dropping any long gun with loaded chamber can be dangerous, the use of a soft bronze bolt in early Stens—allowing the [[Sear (firearm)|sear]] contact area to wear down quickly—made ADs even more likely.
As the early Sten gun illustrates, "poor design," including the specification of unsuitable component materials, is sometimes cited as a cause for some firearms being "unsafe." Surely, any firearm that can discharge by itself when loaded is unsafe, and no user would want to handle a firearm that has a high likelihood of accidental discharge when employed for its intended use. But, firearm designs incorporating fewer safeties are not intrinsically unsafe—see discussion of long-guns above—even if they do require competence and proper training for safe use.
A relevant discussion attends the use of [[Safety (firearms)#Magazine Interlocks|magazine-safeties]] in semi-automatic pistols. Such safeties prevent the pistol from firing if there is a round in the chamber, but the magazine is removed. Some self-defense experts dislike this feature, as it may allow the pistol to be "disabled" unexpectedly during a struggle, so that the pistol fails when needed. Others feel that it may improve user safety and prevent some accidental discharges. Both semi-auto pistol designs, with and without magazine-safeties, are currently manufactured.
One last form of accidental discharge, known as ''[[cooking off]],'' occurs when a weapon becomes overheated, with the firing chamber hot enough to ignite the propellant charge in the ammunition round, causing the cartridge to fire. As recently as 1979, this problem doomed the innovative [[Heckler & Koch G11]] during NATO trials.
"Cooking off" is typically encountered only in [[fully automatic]] weapons, such as [[machine gun]]s, when they are fired for long periods of time without allowing the barrel and chamber of the weapon to cool down to safe temperatures. For this reason, modern crew-served machine guns are equipped with spare [[Gun barrel|barrel]]s to allow a machine gun crew to replace an overheated barrel with a cool one, thus restoring the weapon to action while the overheated barrel is allowed to cool. Also, the majority of machine guns fire from an [[open bolt]], so the round is chambered only after pressing the trigger, just before firing.
==Negligent discharge==
A '''negligent discharge''' ('''ND''') is a discharge of a [[firearm]] involving [[Culpability|culpable]] carelessness. In judicial and military technical terms, a negligent discharge is a chargeable offence. A number of [[armed force]]s automatically consider any [[accidental discharge]] to be negligent discharge, under the assumption that a trained soldier has control of his firearm at all times. This is the case in the [[United States Army]],<ref>Trevino, Abel. "Proper Weapons Practices Key to Ending Negligent Discharge Incidents in Iraq." ''army.mil''. United States Army. 1 March 2007. [http://www.army.mil/-news/2007/03/01/2065-proper-weapons-practices-key-to-ending-negligent-discharge-incidents-in-iraq/]</ref> [[Canadian Army]], the [[Royal Air Force]], the [[British Army]] and various Police Forces within the United Kingdom.
From an article on a U.S. Air Force website: {{quote|A negligent discharge occurs when a weapon is fired due to either operator error or a lack of attention to basic safety rules.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.jber.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123376171 | title=Negligent discharge: Don’t be that guy | publisher=Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson, USAF | date=9 January 2014 | accessdate=18 December 2014 | author=Cunningham, Vernon}}</ref>}}
